member.name: T:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Failures.SaveFailure
member.summary: Defines basic information about a failure that occured during a modification operation.
member.remarks:
Instances for the common failures, such as , may be safely reused, as these are immutable.
Instances returned by must not be reused when reporting failures for unrelated changes, as the contained exception is mutable (all are). Additionally, these are meant to be used to report results when an unexpected error happens, so this is normally in response to an exception that was thrown, which includes additional stacktrace information.

member.summary: A failure indicating a occurred.

member.summary: Contains exception for non-recoverable cases, for example if FailureType property is set to HardFailure. In other cases the property will be null.

member.returns: The failure instance.

member.param: The type of the failure.
member.returns: The
member.exception: was or some unknown

member.name: T:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Failures.SaveFailureType
member.summary: Defines failure types that can occur during update, insert, delete operations.

member.name: F:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Failures.SaveFailureType.ChangeConflict
member.summary: The received entity/facet being updated/deleted had already been changed by another thread/process/application.
member.remarks:
The concurrency token for the updated record is not the same as in the database.
Possible reason: Somebody had updated the same record before you performed the save operation.

member.name: F:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Failures.SaveFailureType.AlreadyExists
member.summary: The received entity/facet/identifier being added had already been added by another thread/process/application.
member.remarks: Note that this only applies for entities that allow to use IDs generated from the client. At the time of writting, this is only for device profiles.

member.name: F:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Failures.SaveFailureType.NotFound
member.summary: The entity/facet being updated/deleted wasn't found in the system.
member.remarks: Possible reason: Somebody had removed the entity/facet before you tried to update/delete it.

member.name: F:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Failures.SaveFailureType.ReferenceNotFound
member.summary: The entity/facet being added/updated points to another entity/facet that's no longer in the system.
member.remarks: Possible reasons: - The entity for the facet being added/updated has been removed by another thread/process/application. - The contact for the interaction being added has been removed by another thread/process/application. - The contact pointed by has been removed by another thread/process/application.

member.name: F:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Failures.SaveFailureType.System
member.summary: There was an unexpected exception when trying to save the changes for the entity/facet.
member.remarks: Possible reasons: connection timeout, inaccessible shard, etc.

member.name: F:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Failures.SaveFailureType.TemporaryUnavailable
member.summary: The record is temporary unavailable to update. Specific to the contact identifier index. The contact identifier index is locked.
member.remarks: Possible reasons: the contact identifier index has been added and locked for some time (in order to complete all other save operations with contact and contact identifiers) and another thread tries to add the same identifier into the index. The temporary unavailable means that contact identifier can't be saved (added/deleted) and can't be treated as already existed identifier, because it might be deleted in case if contact is not saved successfully. The simple retry has to be performed with such type of failure.

member.name: T:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Indexing.RevolvingIndexer
member.summary: Provides indexing capabilities by utilizing , reading ahead data while the previous one is being indexed.
member.remarks: This implementation runs data retrieving ahead of time, while the previous data is being indexed. So by the time it finishes with indexing, the next set to index will already be ready. It runs not more than 2 threads of data preparation and indexing is happening always sequentially, which preserves data consistency.

If or throw an unexpected exception, the caller must use which represents the latest indexed data.
Indexing must then be resumed from there, even if more changed ids had been previously written and the corresponding tokens succesfully signaled.
The above is critical as it would otherwise lead to inconsistent data during automated or manual error recovery.

member.remarks:

member.summary: Signals all changes have been indexed, so the token associated to the index for search reflect this.
member.param: The token indicating all changes have been indexed.
member.remarks: Note to implementers: It is the responsibility of the writer implementation, to make sure the token won't be available to be read before the changes previously written are. This allows clients to wait until the token is available (by checking against ), to make sure the query they issue will see all changes they have previously written to xdb.

member.name: M:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Indexing.Indexer.GetChangedDataRecords(Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.IDataProvider,Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Indexing.IndexerSettings,Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Indexing.ChangedIds,Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.InteractionExpandOptions,Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.EntityExpandOptions)
member.remarks: When a known contact becomes anonymous and is false, the contact will be deleted from the index. The system will also issue deletes for anonymous contacts that got an identifier deleted. While that's an unnecessary extra load in the index, there is a performance trade off between what change tracking needs to detect vs. the extra deletes the index needs to handle cases where an already anonymous contact got an identifier deleted.

member.name: M:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Indexing.Indexer.WriteAbortingOnSyncFailures(System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource,Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.Indexing.ChangedDataRecords)
member.remarks:
This method ensures that after a failure in the synchronous part of , the indexer will already be retrying the next time it calls .
A provider postponing actions can use the above assurance to properly ensure all ongoing actions are aborted and the indexer properly retries based on the current in the index. Without the assurance this method provides, the has no way of determining if the next call of is the indexer moving forward or retrying earlier changes.
This assurance, although used by the azure search provider, may change in the future, so it's not part of the public contracts. When doing so we may introduce mecanisms that make the indexer aware of postponed actions or at least allow the provider to signal the failure in a way that provides the same guarantee. Another alternative that might be used is for the calls to to include information that allows to determine the indexer is moving forward or retrying earlier changes.

member.name: T:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.ChangeSet
member.summary: Contains a set of changes that is processed by .
member.remarks: When updating specific records, such as the , or , all the information in the record must be provided. That is, if you save a record in the changed state with only the id, the appropiate concurrency token and only 1 property set, then it will replace any existing data when it is saved. This does not apply to related records, so facets and interactions does not need to be provided when updating a contact or interaction. The change set must not have duplicate records or facets being updated/deleted, such as 2 ContactDataRecord updating the same contact or one updating and the other deleting it. Contact id in interaction records must match the id of the contact that interactions belong to.

member.name: M:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.ISyncToken.IsUpToDate(Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.ISyncToken)
member.summary: Checks whether this instance has all the changes indicated by .
member.param: The token that indicates the changes to check.
member.returns: true if the current instance has all the changes indicated by
member.remarks: Tokens may have multiple dimensions, such as a value per shard indicating what changes we already have for the branch. In such a case, the current instance is only considered to be up to date with , if it already has the changes for *all* the shards/dimensions of the the other token.

member.summary: An implementation that allows to store and retrieve entities from a physical store.
member.remarks:
This interface is used by the . The main concern of the data provider is the permanent storage of the information, and to allowing the retrieval of the information by id. For interactions, it also must support the retrieval based on contact ids and the options specified in .
From the consuming side, code in the service layer must be used, instead of direct calls to the or the .

member.name: M:Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.IDataProvider.Save(Sitecore.Xdb.Collection.ChangeSet)
member.summary: Saves the changes in the .
member.returns: The that includes any failed changes.
member.remarks: The data provider updates the id and concurrency token in the instances passed in for the succesfully added records. When updates are succesfull, the concurrency token is replaced with the new one in the corresponding instance. The data provider does not have restrictions when adding/updating facets for a previously saved interaction, as it is only higher layers of the system that constraint the modification of interactions that have already been submitted for aggregation. Notes to inheritors: while we will advise consumers to avoid sending really large amount of changes, the data provider must be prepared to take in large sets. When necessary this may mean splitting the changes when storing those in the physical stores.

Rather than loading and returning all the specified contacts in memory, these are returned in smaller subsets represented by .
Any system failures when retrieving the data are raised as an when doing the async enumeration of the . In this case, no further subsets can be retrieved as the enumeration is closed and the exception is propagated.
The received ids are first divided in subsets of , and retrieved from the data store only one subset at a time. Only when we are done with the subset, we retrieve a new subset.
The found contacts in the subset are further divided into smaller subsets of . Depending on the , the related interactions are loaded only for each of the smaller subset at a time. These smaller subsets are what we return in , and only when the consumer moves to the next smaller subset we retrieve the next related interactions. Once we are done with the smaller subsets, we retrieve the next set of contacts from the The order in which contacts are returned is not guaranteed to be the same as the order of .
